security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only skill containing documentation and usage examples. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, and no external commands. The embedded scripts are documentation examples only.

content.value_statement: Writing changelogs manually is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill parses your git commit history following conventional commits and semantic versioning to automatically generate professional, organized changelogs.
actual_capabilities: Parse git commit messages following conventional commit format
Identify commit types (feat, fix, docs, refactor, and more)
Group changes by category and determine version bumps
Suggest semantic version numbers based on commits
limitations: Requires git repository with commit history
Works best with conventional commit message format
Does not auto-commit or push changes

use_cases.title: Release documentation
use_cases.description: Generate professional changelogs for each release to inform users of new features and fixes.

use_cases.title: CI/CD automation
use_cases.description: Integrate changelog generation into release pipelines with automated version bumps.

use_cases.title: Project documentation
use_cases.description: Maintain clear records of changes for internal projects and client documentation.

prompt_templates.title: Basic changelog
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a changelog for all commits since the last tag. Use conventional commit format to categorize changes into features, fixes, and documentation updates.

prompt_templates.title: Version-specific
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a changelog for version 2.0.0. Include breaking changes prominently at the top. Format using Keep a Changelog standard.

prompt_templates.title: Unreleased changes
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me the unreleased changelog with all commits since the previous release. Group by type and include commit hashes.

prompt_templates.title: Full release notes
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate complete release notes including version suggestion based on semantic versioning rules, changelog entry, migration guide for breaking changes, and links to commits.

output_examples.input: Generate a changelog for commits since v1.5.0
output: - Migrated from REST to GraphQL - requires API update

best_practices: Use conventional commit messages (feat:, fix:, docs:, etc.) to enable automatic parsing
Include breaking changes with clear migration instructions for users
Review generated changelogs before publishing to ensure clarity and completeness
anti_patterns: Skipping changelog generation and leaving users uninformed about changes
Using vague commit messages that cannot be categorized automatically
Failing to document breaking changes prominently

faq.question: What commit formats are supported?
faq.answer: Conventional commits with type, optional scope, and description. Examples: feat: new login or fix(auth): resolve token issue.

faq.question: How are version numbers determined?
faq.answer: Breaking changes trigger major version bumps. New features trigger minor version bumps. Fixes trigger patch version bumps.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with CI/CD?
faq.answer: Yes. Use tools like standard-version or release-please to automate changelog generation in your pipeline.

faq.question: Is my commit data safe?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only reads your local git history. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why is my changelog empty?
faq.answer: Ensure commits follow conventional format. Non-conventional commits are grouped as Other Changes or may be skipped.

faq.question: How does this compare to git log?
faq.answer: This skill categorizes and formats commits professionally. git log shows raw history without organization or semantic versioning.
